For an element $a \in M$ of a monoid and an exponent $n \in \mathbb{N}$, the $n$th power of $a$, denoted $a^n$, is defined in the usual way. Note that $a^0 = e$, following the convention on empty products.

Given a normal subgroup $N \subset G$ of a group $G$, the factor group or the residue class group of $G$ modulo $N$, denoted $G / N$, is the group formed by the set of left cosets of $N$ in $G$ with the group operation defined by $(aN) \cdot (bN) = (ab)N$ for $a, b \in G$.

Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.

An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.

Given a ring $R$ and a multiplicative system $S \subset R$, the localization $S^{-1}R$ (or $R_S$) is the ring of fractions $ rac{a}{s}$ where $a \in R$ and $s \in S$, under an equivalence relation defined by $ rac{a}{s} =  rac{a'}{s'}$ if there exists some $s'' \in S$ such that $as's'' = a'ss''$.
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).

An ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) in a ring \(R\) is called reduced if \(\mathfrak{a} = \operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\), where \(\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\) is the set of all elements \(a \in R\) such that there exists some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(a^{n} \in \mathfrak{a}\).
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.
